did.head: Collection Summary
did.abstract: This collection consists of news articles, memorabilia, and correspondence. This correspondence is between the Army Corp of Engineers and various townsmen but mainly Aaron Rabinowitz.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: The federal government purchased 7.35 acres from Aaron Rabinowitz for $35,000 in 1955 which were used as a Nike station to protect Bridgeport industry during the Cold War. Mr. Rabinowitz was chairman of the board of the Fred F. French Investing Co. He founded the Tudor Foundation, in 1945, a charitable trust. The federal government released the Nike site land to the town of Westport in 1964. Mr. Rabinowitz's hope to donate $50,000 for a branch of the library to be built on the site in the name of Lillian Wald was not successful.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: This collection is primarily dated correspondence between Aaron Rabinowitz and the federal government. Also, there is correspondence from then First Selectman Herb Baldwin and Congressman Abner Sibal. It should be noted that there is a memo from Cyrus Vance then the Deputy Secretary of Defense. Included are newspapers articles. There are two folders-Aaron Rabinowitz's sale of property to the federal government for the Nike site, Bayberry Lane and efforts for regaining the Nike Site (Bayberry Lane) for town use.
